text.*:
A plate of testaroli, an ancient dish, served with pesto at a trattoria in Pontremoli, Italy

This is a list of ancient dishes, foods and beverages that have been recorded as originating during ancient history. The span of recorded history is roughly 5,000 years, beginning with Sumerian Cuneiform script, the oldest discovered form of coherent writing from the protoliterate period around the 30th century BC.[1]

Ancient history can be defined as occurring from the beginning of recorded human history to:

  • The Early Middle Ages (the end of the 4th century AD)
  • The fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 AD[2][3]
  • The Postclassical Era (200-600 AD and 1200–1500 AD, depending on the continent)[4][5][6][7]

Although the end date of ancient history is disputed, some Western scholars use the fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 AD (the most used),[8][9] the closure of the Platonic Academy in 529 AD,[10] the death of the emperor Justinian I in 565 AD,[11] the birth of Islam in 610 CE[12] or the rise of Charlemagne[13] as the end of ancient and Classical European history. This list does not contain entries that originated after ancient history.

Beginning of recorded history to 476 AD[edit]

This section is limited to dishes that originated during the time of ancient history (the beginning of recorded human history) up to the Fall of the Western Roman Empire in 476 AD.

Congee
Ruins of a garum factory in Baelo Claudia, Spain
Papadzules may be "one of the most ancient traditional dishes of Yucatán, Mexico.[14]
Various chutneys in Banglore, India
  • Anfu ham is a dry-cured ham from Anfu, Jiangxi, China that originated from the Qin Dynasty.[15] It is eaten alone and also used as an ingredient to add flavor to various dishes.[15]
  • Babaofan or Eight Treasure Glutinous Rice was first created for a banquet celebrating King Wu of Zhou's defeat of the last King of the Shang Dynasty King Zhou of Shang in the Battle of Muye (circa 1123 BCE according to this article but 1046 BCE according to English Wikipedia article).[16]
  • Bread[17][18][19]
    • Flatbread[20]
    • Focaccia – dates to ancient Rome[21][22]
    • Mantou - dates to 307 BCE - 250 BCE [23]
  • Chili pepper (hot peppers) – remains of wild peppers were found in the Tehuacan Valley, 250 kilometres (160 mi) south of Mexico City, Mexico that date back to 7,000 BC.[24] The peppers were found in fossilized human coprolites (fossilized human feces).[24]
  • Chutney[25]
  • Congee[26]
  • Curry[27]
  • Doubanjiang oral history suggests 536 BCE - 448 BCE; first recorded history found in a text from the Western Han Dynasty (206 BCE - 9 CE)[28]
  • Fish sauce, see Garum
  • Forcemeat[29]
  • Garum, ancient Greece (γάρος) and Roman Empire, known from before Pompeii's destruction in 79 AD[30][31]
  • Ham – dry-cured ham has been produced since ancient times.[32][33][34]
  • Harissa
  • Jeok
  • Jusselle[35]
  • Liquamen, see Garum
  • Maccu[36]
  • Misu karu or Misugaru[37]
  • Moretum[38]
  • Nian gao[39]
  • Noodle – existent since at least 2,000 BC in Northwest China,[40][41] the noodle was developed independently in ancient China and ancient Rome, and remained common in both areas "through the centuries".[42]
  • Olive, olive oil from Eastern Mediterranean in Bronze Age, c. 3000 BC[43][44]
  • Oxygala – a dairy product in ancient Greece and Rome.[45] It was also consumed by ancient Persians.[46]
  • Papadzules – a common dish in Maya cuisine that may be "one of the most ancient traditional dishes of Yucatán, Mexico.[14]
  • Placenta cake – a layered cake of pastry, cheese and honey[47][48]
  • Rice[49] – existed, but was "little-used in the ancient world" outside of Asia.[50]
Sauerkraut
  • Sauerkraut[51]
  • Sausage[a][53]
    • Lucanica, Western Roman Empire, mentioned by Cicero, 1st century BC[54][55]
  • Sop[56]
  • Soup[b]
    • Acquacotta[58]
    • Black soup[59]
    • French onion soup[56]
    • Vegetable soup[60]
  • Soy Sauce[61]
  • Tamale[62]
  • Testaroli[63][64]
  • Tharida[65]
  • Tofu[66]
  • Torta de gazpacho[citation needed]
  • Tracta was a kind of bread, pastry, or pancake in ancient Greece and perhaps Rome.[67]
  • Wonton[68]
  • Zongzi[69]
  • Ancient dishes

  • Acquacotta

  • Flatbread

Beverages[edit]

  • Beer is recorded in the written history of Mesopotamia and ancient Egypt and is one of the world's oldest prepared beverages.[70]
  • Kombucha originated in what is now Manchuria around 220 BCE, and is said to have been imported to Japan around 400 CE by the physician Kombu.[71][72]
  • Soy milk has been consumed in China since ancient times.[73]
  • Wine consumption and production has been found through archaeological evidence as early as c. 6000 BC.[74][75]

Cereals and grains[edit]

Further information: Ancient grains
Farro may be one of the "most ancient of all ancient grains."[76]
  • Amaranth grain – grain and plant bundles were found by archaeologists at the Tehuacán caves in Central Mexico that date back to around 5,500 years.[77] The grain continues to be grown in the area in contemporary times.[77]
  • Barley[78]
  • Bulgur (burghul) – existed Anno Domini in the Near East[45]
  • Farro – may be one of the "most ancient of all ancient grains"[76]
  • Hemp seed – used as a food grain in Ancient China up to the time of the Han Dynasty, at which time its use declined and then stopped.[79] This was documented as "the prevailing view" in the book Fermentations and Food Science.[79]
  • Kasha (buckwheat groats) – first cultivated in China, they were later cultivated in Eastern Europe.[80] The food is still commonly used in both regions.[80]
  • Millet – a staple food of ancient China, Egypt and India; Staple in Northern China before rice.[80]
  • Rice - originated in Southern China 8,200 - 13,500 years ago.
  • Wheat[78][81]
    • Einkorn wheat – may be one of the "most ancient of all ancient grains"[76]
    • Spelt – a common grain in Switzerland and Germany "by the seventh century BCE"[82] (BC) Spelt existed in Great Britain since 500 BCE.[82]
  • Teff - a native grain to Ethiopia and Eritrea that happened to be domesticated sometime between 8000 and 5000 BC.[83]
  • Ancient cereals and grains

  • Buckwheat kasha

  • Millet flour

Dairy products[edit]

Quark
  • Butter – documented as existent since at least 2,000 BC[84]
  • Buttermilk – existed Anno Domini in India[45]
  • Kumis – documented as existing in ancient Scythia[45]
  • Milk[85]
  • Opus lactarum – documented as existing during the ancient Roman Empire[45]
  • Quark (lac concretum) – documented as existing in ancient Scythia[45]
  • Schiston – "separated milk" purported to have been invented by physicians during the time of the Ancient Roman Empire and Pliny the Elder[45][86] It was prepared by boiling milk or whey along with pebbles.[86][87]
  • Shrikhand – documented as existing circa 800 to 300 B.C. in ancient India[45]
  • Smy – thickened milk[c] documented as existent in ancient Egypt[45]
  • Yogurt[89] – documented as existing in India circa 300 BC to 75 AD; referred to as "dahi"[45]

Cheeses[edit]

Pecorino Romano is one of the world's most ancient cheeses
  • Cheese[d][91]
  • Brânză– an ancient Romanian cheese dating to "before the time of the Romans"[92]
  • Caciocavallo
  • Cantal cheese – one of the oldest French cheeses, it is named after the Cantal mountain range[93]
  • Castelmagno cheese[94]
    • Emmental cheese[95]
  • Feta – existed during the times of Homer in ancient Greece[96]
    • Touloumotiri is an ancient cheese that is considered as the "forerunner to feta".[97]
  • Kefalotyri – dates to the Byzantine Empire[98]
  • Pecorino Romano – is one of the world's most ancient cheeses[99][100]
  • Pecorino Sardo (Flore sardo) – one of the world's oldest cheeses that is believed to date back to the Bronze Age[101]
  • Pecorino Siciliano[102]
  • Roquefort[103][104][105]
  • Tomme[106]
    • Tomme de Savoie[107]
  • Ancient cheeses

  • Cantal cheese

  • Feta

  • Tomme de Savoie

Legumes[edit]

  • Mung bean – a food crop of Southwest Asia from ancient times[108]
  • Soybean[109] – an ancient food crop in China, Japan and Korea[110]

Seeds[edit]

  • Chia has been cultivated by the Aztecs, Mayans, Incas and "other ancient Native American cultures" for over 5,000 years.[111]

AD 477–1500[edit]

This section includes dishes, foods and beverages that originated during the time of ancient history from 477 AD to 1500 AD (prior to the Postclassical Era).

  • Börek is known from 14th century Persia in a poem by Bushaq-i-Atima, and it may be far older.[112][113]
  • Hummus first mentioned in a cookbook from Cairo, Egypt from the 13th century.
  • Kuluban – an ancient Javanese dish of boiled vegetables served in spices, similar with today urap. Mentioned in The Rukam inscription dated 829 Saka (907 CE) from Mataram kingdom ancient Java, Indonesia.[114]
  • Lalab – vegetable dish called as rumwah-rumwah in ancient Java, Indonesia. Mentioned in The Panggumulan (Kembang Arum) inscription dated 824 Saka (902 CE) from Mataram kingdom.[115]
  • Rawon – meat stew, mentioned as rarawwan in ancient Javanese Taji inscription (901 CE).[116]
  • Rujak – spicy fruit dish, mentioned as rurujak in ancient Javanese Taji inscription (901 CE).[116]
  • Krupuk – traditional cracker made from rice flour, mentioned as kurupuk in ancient Javanese Taji inscription (901 CE).[116]
  • Popcorn – an ancient food used by people of the Inca civilization.[80]
  • Philippine adobo - a dish and cooking process originating during the Pre-colonial Philippines. [117]
  • Tapuy - rice wine from the Pre-colonial Philippines. [117]
  • Tempeh - high protein fermented soy product from Indonesia. First known as kadêlê mentioned in an old Javanese manuscript Serat Sri Tanjung from the 12th to 13th century CE.

  • Börek

  • Kuluban or urap

  • Fried tempeh

Cereals and grains[edit]

  • Amaranth was used by the Aztec people (14th–16th centuries).[80]
  • Quinoa – an ancient food crop[118] used by people of the Inca civilization.[119] Quinoa remains as a staple food of importance in South America.[119]

Defined as ancient, but lacking time frame[edit]

A bowl of poi showing a typical consistency
  • Khanom chan – an ancient Thai dessert
  • Poi is an ancient Polynesian staple food prepared using taro root.[e]

Legumes[edit]

  • Chickpea – an ancient food crop in the Ethiopian Highlands[f]

Seeds[edit]

  • Sesame seed is an ancient food.[122]

Likely ancient in origin[edit]

  • Nattō is prepared using fermented soybeans, and has been described as likely being an ancient food.[123] Its origins have been described as unknown.[123] Nattō may have been developed independently in different areas that have the same ingredients, such as Japan, China and Korea.[123]

  • Nattō is typically consumed atop rice.

  • Old World wine
  • Popina – an ancient Roman wine bar, where a limited menu of simple foods (olives, bread, stews) and selection of wines of varying quality were available

Notes[edit]

  1. ^ "The origin of sausage goes back to ancient times."[52]
  2. ^ "An ancient food, soup is prepared by cooking meat, fish or vegetables and the like in such fluids as water or milk; it is then consumed as a liquid."[57]
  3. ^ "Smy, or thickened milk, both human and animal, is often mentioned in medical prescriptions."[88]
  4. ^ "Cheese is represented in the tomb art of ancient Egypt and in Greek literature"[90]
  5. ^ "In the Pacific Islands, poi, made from taro root, is an ancient food that is preserved through fermentation."[120]
  6. ^ "Chickpea is an ancient food crop in the Highlands, but whether it was domesticated indigenously is debatable. Ethiopian varieties are infertile when crossed with Near Eastern varieties. This genetic incompatibility may reflect distinct ecological ..."[121]

"A Review on Kombucha Tea—Microbiology, Composition, Fermentation, Beneficial Effects, Toxicity, and Tea Fungus". Comprehensive Reviews in Food Science and Food Safety. 13: 538–550. doi:10.1111/1541-4337.12073. Fermentation of sugared tea with a symbiotic culture of acetic acid bacteria and yeast (tea fungus) yields kombucha tea which is consumed worldwide for its refreshing and beneficial properties on human health. Important progress has been made in the past decade concerning research findings on kombucha tea and reports claiming that drinking kombucha can prevent various types of cancer and cardiovascular diseases, promote liver functions, and stimulate the immune system. CS1 maint: Multiple names: authors list (link)
